history.content:
Hi!

By meeting the 3.3GPA cap, you are essentially guaranteed to declare the CS major but anything below that is not guaranteed. I highly encourage you to try your best to meet the 3.3GPA cap but in the case that you're a bit below, you should still petition for the major.

If you're applying with below a 3.3GPA, you should definitely fill out the personal statement section (not sure what it's called but there's a portion where you can fill in text). I would say that if you have a 3.2+, you have a decent shot at declaring if you have a strong personal statement detailing why you think you weren't able to meet the 3.3 cap and also you want to portray your interest in CS. Perhaps talk about side projects, your experiences with CS-related work (lab assisting, internships), etc. 

If you have a 3.1+, I would say it's a lot harder to declare but still not impossible. It'll all come down to your circumstances that you explain in your personal statement (although these circumstances will likely have to be quite extreme). 

Getting into upper division CS classes as a non-major is relatively hard since you cannot phase I upper-div courses and popular classes like CS188 fill up really quickly. However, I have known people to get into upper-div courses as a non-major so it is definitely not impossible.

Good luck!

children.subject: hilfinger is the one who processes the applications ?!
if you're below the cap, Hilfiger makes the final decision. The CS advisors will read your personal statement first though

My friends were declaring at the beginning of this semester, as was I. According to Hunn, the leniency is on a semester-by-semester case-by-case approval. For that semester, the leniency was 3.21+ and the approval basically dependent on how Hilfiger felt about your personal statement at the end of the day. Those who applied with 3.2s in spring 16 all got in, the caveat that there were 2 people like that in total. My advice would be to not bank on it

history.content: I know that the 3.0 GPA requirement was known to be lenient (with around 0.2-3 wiggle room), but I've heard that the 3.3 GPA cap is absolute. It is likely that I might end up with a 3.1 or a 3.2 but I think if I intentionally fail and retake the class I can perform better. Although this sounds unethical, I hear it is really difficult to get into a lot of upper division CS classes as a non-major. How lenient (if at all?) is the CS declaration GPA currently?
